notes.text:
An update for kernel-rt is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.2 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The kernel-rt packages provide the Real Time Linux Kernel, which enables fine-tuning for systems with extremely high determinism requirements.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: improper initialization of the "flags" member of the new pipe_buffer (CVE-2022-0847)

* kernel: fget: check that the fd still exists after getting a ref to it (CVE-2021-4083)

* kernel: possible privileges escalation due to missing TLB flush (CVE-2022-0330)

* kernel: cgroups v1 release_agent feature may allow privilege escalation (CVE-2022-0492)

* kernel: failing usercopy allows for use-after-free exploitation (CVE-2022-22942)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.

Bug Fix(es):

* kernel-rt: update RT source tree to the latest RHEL-8.2.z16 Batch (BZ#2057698)
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')

notes.text: A read-after-free memory flaw was found in the Linux kernel's garbage collection for Unix domain socket file handlers in the way users call close() and fget() simultaneously and can potentially trigger a race condition. This flaw allows a local user to crash the system or escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: fget: check that the fd still exists after getting a ref to it
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation for this issue is either not available or the currently available options don't meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base, or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: fget: check that the fd still exists after getting a ref to it

notes.text: A random memory access flaw was found in the Linux kernelâs GPU i915 kernel driver functionality in the way a user may run malicious code on the GPU. This flaw allows a local user to crash the system or escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: possible privileges escalation due to missing TLB flush
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: For the Red Hat Enterprise Linux default configuration, the issue occurs only if a local user is running malicious code on GPU. The GPU is used and the user is required to have privileges to access the i915 Intel GPU.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation for this issue is either not available or the currently available options don't meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base, or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: possible privileges escalation due to missing TLB flush

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in the Linux kernelâs cgroup_release_agent_write in the kernel/cgroup/cgroup-v1.c function. This flaw, under certain circumstances, allows the use of the cgroups v1 release_agent feature to escalate privileges and bypass the namespace isolation unexpectedly.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: cgroups v1 release_agent feature may allow privilege escalation
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
In the OpenShift Container Platform (OCP) the container escape and privilege escalation caused by the CVE-2022-0492 vulnerability are blocked by the SELinux policy enabled (by default) on the OCP cluster nodes.

Red Hat Virtualization requires SELinux running in enforcing mode[1] on all hypervisors and managers, which blocks this vulnerability.

1. https://access.redhat.com/solutions/499473
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: cgroups v1 release_agent feature may allow privilege escalation

notes.text: A flaw was found in the way the "flags" member of the new pipe buffer structure was lacking proper initialization in copy_page_to_iter_pipe and push_pipe functions in the Linux kernel and could thus contain stale values. An unprivileged local user could use this flaw to write to pages in the page cache backed by read only files and as such escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: improper initialization of the "flags" member of the new pipe_buffer
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
Red Hat Product Security is aware of this issue. Updates will be released as they become available.

Note that PIPE_BUF_FLAG_CAN_MERGE flag attack vector is not available in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 and thus the currently known exploits leveraging this flag do not work. The underlying issue (lack of proper pipe_buffer structure initialization) is still present though and other novel ways leading to successful exploitation cannot be fully ruled out.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.
Currently there is no mitigation available for this flaw. Customers should update to fixed packages, once they are available.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: improper initialization of the "flags" member of the new pipe_buffer

notes.text: A use-after-free flaw was found in the Linux kernelâs vmw_execbuf_copy_fence_user function in drivers/gpu/drm/vmwgfx/vmwgfx_execbuf.c in vmwgfx. This flaw allows a local attacker with user privileges to cause a privilege escalation problem.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: failing usercopy allows for use-after-free exploitation
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation for this issue is to skip loading the affected module vmwgfx onto the system until we have a fix available. This can be done by a blacklist mechanism and ensures the driver is not loaded at the boot time.
~~~
How do I blacklist a kernel module to prevent it from loading automatically?
https://access.redhat.com/solutions/41278 
~~~

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: failing usercopy allows for use-after-free exploitation
